cannot say exactly how long I have left—this Saturday night was not a light, it was a dark night—I heard Mr. Miller speak—I cannot exactly say what he said—he did not say he was insulted by the poor voters—he said he was much fatigued, and he hoped they would be early on Monday. morning in coming forward—his hat was off—I saw him clearly—I know Mr. Badnall—I saw him at Newcastle, and I have seen him since I come to town, going along the Old Bailey, and at the New inn, I think they call it, just across the way—I did not go there to see him—I did not go on purpose to see him—I could not be long with him, perhaps it might be five minutes—that was not to-day—it was on Saturday—I cannot say that I was ever in the employ of a man of the name of Cox—I do not re
collect the name—I worked at Mr. Cox's shop some years since—I do not know Union-hall—I was taken to some police-office, and went to gaol for a month.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What sort of a shop was it? A. My work was there, and I was going to take it to another place, and somebody said that I was going to take it away—it was not Mr. Cox's work—I was never tried before that time, and then I was sent by the Justice for a month.

COURT. Q. Were you tried in any Court, or committed by the Ma
gistrate? A. I do not know—I was before some persons—I was tried at a bar something similar to this—I cannot say what place they called it—I had never been in a Court of Justice before that time—I believe there was a Jury—it was several years ago—I cannot say exactly how long, it may be six, seven, or eight years.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you been working for Mr. Mason since that time? A. Yes.

CHARLES FRANCIS . I am a trunkmaker, living in Lower-street, New
castle. I know the Royal Express beer-shop, or public-house—I was there on Saturday, the nomination evening before the last election, between eight and nine o'clock—I know Mr. Miller, the member—he came into the Royal Express beer-shop—I do not know Mr. Mason—there were several gen
tlemen with him—the name of the landlord is Mr. Boot—some gentleman with Mr. Miller asked him for his vote in his hearing—I was coming out of the house at the same time—I afterwards saw Mr. Miller canvassing the voters in Lower-street, and I saw him at the Castle hotel—before that I saw him at the bottom of Church-lane—I was at the Castle about half-past nine o'clock, or a quarter to ten—I went there to hear Mr. Miller address the people—while I was standing there, I saw Mr. Miller—he went into the Castle hotel, and a gentleman had hold of his arm—when he got in he came to the window, and made a short speech—I heard that.

Cross-examined by MR. KELLY. Q. What time was this? A. Nearer ten o'clock than nine—a young man of the name of Thomas Patmore was with me, he is a shoemaker—I have lived some years in Newcastle—I am not a voter—I am no relation or connexion of Gallimore's—my wife is no relation of him, nor his wife—we did not marry two sisters—there is no con
nexion, or kindred, between my wife and his—my wife's maiden name was Amelia Downs—I do not know who the prisoner married—his brother married a sister of my wife's.

Q. What is the reason you did not tell me that? A. That is no con
nexion of mine—I never thought about it—it was getting dusk, but quite light enough for anybody to distinguish a man's face—I swear that.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Would that depend upon how near he was to the
window? A. I was exactly under the window—I know that Patmore has left Newcastle since that time.

1365.
THOMAS SULLINS was indicted
for killing and slaying
Thomas Boulter.

DANIEL BOULTER . I am a waterman, and live in Ann's-row, Bromley; the deceased, Thomas Boulter, was my brother. On Monday morning, the 26th of March, I heard what was about to take place, and went down to the marshes in Essex, near the river Lea—I saw Curtis, Tantony, and Blaker, and my brother come in a boat—I saw the prisoner there—a fight took place between my brother and Blaker—the prisoner picked my brother up, and put him on another man's knee—he continued to do so during the fight, and he wished him to leave off—they fought about thirty-five minutes—I saw Blaker strike my brother a blow with the right hand under the left ear—it appeared a chance blow—he fell down, and never was sensible afterwards—he was put into a boat and taken away.

MARGARET WILSON . I live in Gardiner-place, Poplar. I knew the deceased—I was present at the Angel public-house, when there was a dis
pute between him and Blaker—I was present on Monday, the 26th of March, at the marshes, hearing a fight was to take place—I did not see him pick him up—I was not very near—the prisoner came there in the boat with the rest, and remained till it was over—I did not see Boulter fall the last time.

WILLIAM BAIN . I am a surgeon, and live in Brunswick-street, Poplar. On Monday, the 26th of March, I was called in to see the deceased—I found him at hi, lodging, in Leicester-street—he was insensible, and never became sensible—he died about two hours after I arrived—there were several con
tusions on his face and head—there was a post mortem examination—the im
mediate cause of death was the rupture of a Wood-vessel in the head, which might be produced by a violent blow in a fight—he had every appearance of having been engaged in fighting—there was a blow immediately below the left ear—I have not a doubt death was occasioned by blows received in fighting—after having heard the evidence, I believe that was the occasion of his death.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 26th of March Boulter called me up, as I live with his mother—I went down to see the fight, but not to be second—I wiped his face several times—I tried to persuade him to leave off fighting—he said no, he would not; he had brought forty people there to see the fight, and he would not make fools of them—at last I caught hold of him, and said he should leave off fighting, I would have no more of it—Blaker came up to shake hands with him, but he got out of my hands, and fell down on the grass—I took him to his mothers, and went for the surgeon.

GUILTY. Aged 29.—Recommended to mercy —
Confined One Month .
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1366.
WILLIAM STEVENS was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Samuel Wood, about the hour of twelve, in the night of the 30th of September, 1836, with intent to steal, and stealing therein part of a snuff-box, value 1d.; and 13 buttons, value 4d. his property.

SAMUEL WOOD . I live in Barking-side, Essex, and am a labouring man. In September, 1836, I occupied a cottage there—nobody lived in but I and my wife—on the morning of the 30th of September I and my wife went out to work about five or six o'clock—the door was fastened with a chain—it was not locked—the bed-room window was shut, I am certain—it is on the ground-floor, and is a sash-window—I fastened the door with a chain, and tied it with a string—we returned about twelve o'clock at night, and found the door fastened, as we had left it—the window was taken out, and stood down, inside the room—I opened the door and went in, and found the prisoner partly under the bed—the things were taken out of the boxes and drawers, and lying all about the room—I knew the prisoner—he pulled the top of my snuff-box out of his pocket, and gave it to me—I had left it in the box in the morning—the moon shone in at the window, and my wife fetched a light—I am sure it was him—I asked him what business he had there—he said he thought he was in his own house—I can
not say he was sober, nor yet altogether tipsy—I let him go, being a neigh
bour—I never saw him again till he was apprehended—he lived close to me, but I never saw him—I did not trouble myself to inquire for him—I had not heard anybody moving about before I went in, but we perceived a light in the house.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. It was a back window; I be
lieve it was open? A. Yes—we came up to prosecute the prisoner, after he was taken on another charge—Smith, the officer, came after me—the pri
soner had not been living in the county all the time, that I know of—this is the top of the snuff-box—(producing it)—it is of no value—his moths gave my wife thirteen buttons in the morning—it was not dark when we went out in the morning—we were away the whole day—I did not go be
fore the Magistrate to make a charge—the Magistrate sent for me—the constable went into his house, and I after him, that night, after I let him go, but did not find him.
COURT. Q. What things were taken out of the boxes, and scattered about the room? A. Clothes and bed-furniture.
HARRIETT WOOD . I am the wife of the prosecutor. I went out, and fastened the door myself, and the windows—the bed-room window was shut—I got some buttons from somebody the next morning.
NOT GUILTY .

1367.
WILLIAM STEVENS was again indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of April, 1 watch value 26s.; 1 watch-chain, value 2d.; 1 watch-key, value 2d.; and 1 fourpenny-piece; the goods and money of
Daniel Mur
ray, from his person.

DANIEL MURRAY . On the 5th of April I was at Hunt's beer-shop, at Barking—I had a watch in my watch-pocket—I had been drinking—I went out into the back-part of the premises, and fell asleep—I know my watch was safe when I went out of the door—Willis, my mate, missed it before I did.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSOH. Q. You had been drinking rather much perhaps? A. I do not think I had, but J had plenty—I cannot whether I had my watch in my pocket when I was in the privy—in buttoning, to put my watch into my fob, I may have missed my fob, and dropped it.

THOMAS SMITH . I am a constable. In consequence of information I apprehended the prisoner, on the 10th of May, about ten o'clock at night, Hollingsworth's beer-shop, which is rather above a mile from Hunt's—I found the watch on him—before I found it he said he would show me the an he got the watch from—we let him go.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you constable of the parish in 1836? A. yes—the prisoner had been drinking, but was not tipsy—he could walk—e had not been drinking to excess—he was perfectly sober and sensible—knew where to find the prisoner respecting the last case—I took him be
fore the Magistrate after I had this charge—Wood lives at Barking-side, four miles from Barking.

JAMES HUNT . I was fourteen years old last November—I am the son John Hunt who keeps the beer-shop at Barking—I know the prisoner—he was at my father's house on the 5th of April—I was in the next privy Murray between six and seven o'clock—the prisoner came to me and lid, "Where is Dan?"—I said, "In the next privy asleep"—he laid, "Let him have an hour or two's sleep, it will do him good"—and then he went away. I saw no more of him.

JAMES WILLIS . I was with Murray at Hunt's beer-shop on the 5th of April—I recollect his going out of the house—I remained in the house—I was sober—he went out of the house about ten minutes after six o'clock at night—I went to look for him about a quarter past six o'clock, and found him asleep in the privy—I cannot tell whether he had his watch with him or not—I shut the door and left him there—I went again in about half an hour, he was still asleep—I examined, and his watch was not in his fob, nor about his person—when I could not find it I awoke him—I took him back into the house—the prisoner was then in the house—I said in his hearing that Murray had lost his watch, that somebody in the house must know something about it, and before anybody went out of the house every man should be searched—the prisoner got up and said he would search me first—he did so, and then I searched him—I could not find it—every body was searched in the house—there were ten or twelve there, all men—the prisoner afterwards said he had three or four miles to go, and he would be there on the following night, and he left about half-past eight or nine o'clock—the watch was missed before seven o'clock—the search took place about a quarter of an hour after that—I had looked about the pre
mises before I searched.

Cross-examined. Q. Had several of you been drinking at that shop? A. Murray had and the rest—he had no more than to be capable of taking care of himself—I searched all over the prisoner, all about his clothes and pockets—he had unbuttoned his jacket and taken it off, and I searched his trowsers.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Park.

1368.
THOMAS WOOD was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Wells, at
Wanstead, about the hour of two in the morning of the 4th of May, with intent to steal, and steal-ing therein 2 pairs of candlesticks, value 1l. 10s.; 1 pair of snuffers tray, value 1l.; 2 cruet-stands, value 1l. 10s.; 8 cruets, value 1l. 1 waiter, value 1l. 10s.; 2 table-covers, value 1l.; 1 pair of decantes stands, value 10s.; and 4 sheets, value 5s.; his goods.

ANN DICKENSON . I am servant to Mr. Thomas Wells—my husbead is also in his service—we live in his house, which is in the parish of was stead, Essex—he rents the house. On the night of Friday, the 4th of may Mr. Wells was the last person up—I went to bed at ten o'clock—I faster all the doors and windows safely myself—I left nobody up but Mr. Web—I came down at a quarter before six o'clock the next morning, as the patrol rang at the kitchen bell—I found the shutter of the dining-room forced open, which I am quite certain I had fastened—the bolt was broken off and the bar quite bent—the dining-room faces a lawn at the back the house—I missed a pair of plated candlesticks, snuffers, and tray, the dining-room, also two red table-covers, two sets of castors and stand four shells, and a plated waiter—I found on the lawn a tea-chest broken open and a hammer, which had been taken out of the table drawer, and a take lamp—everything but the shells were brought back again that day.

THOMAS WELLS . I live in the parish of Wanstead. I went to bed in mediately after the servant—I did not alter the doors or windows called me about six o'clock in the morning—I found the shutter broke I missed the articles she named, and the shells—I saw my property she afterwards at the house of Mr. Plaxton, a neighbour, whose watchman had stopped a man with them—I knew them again, and I know the shells from seeing them constantly on the mantel-piece—the value of the property is about 12l.

PATRICK MAHONET . I am watchman to Mr. Plaxton. About a quarter past four o'clock, on Saturday morning, the 5th of May, I saw a young; lad in one of my master's fields, about four hundred yards from Mr. Wells's—I asked him what he was doing there—he said, "Nothing"—I cannot tell who it was—I do not know the prisoner—I opened the gate, and went in, and there stood a basket by him—I had some conversation with him about it—I stooped down to open it, and then he ran away—I took it to master's house—the prisoner is not the man I am certain.

JOSEPH MATTHEWS . I am watchman of Stratford Broadway, Essex. On Friday night, between the 4th and 5th of May, I saw two men, between twelve and one o'clock, about half a mile from Mr. Wells's house—I am sure the prisoner was one of them—they' were down an area, at the back of an inhabited house—I spoke to them, collared the prisoner, brought him out of the yard, and asked him what he did in the area—he said he got in there to sleep, to lie down a bit—I rang the house-bell, for some time, and the other man came to him, and said, "Slip your coat off"—he slipped one arm off his shoulder, and the other man began to knock me about—they did not knock me down, but both got away from me—I am quite sure the prisoner was one of them—I did not know him before, but saw him again the next morning, about half-past three o'clock, coming to wards London, in a straight direction from Mr. Wells's, about half a mile from it—I said, "Good morning"—he said, "Good morning, what o'clock is it?"—I said, "Half-past three"—he said, "Is it as much as that?"—I said nothing about having seen him the night before—he kept walking on, and I followed him, till I saw one of my men, named "King George"—I
held up my hand, and he stopped him, put his hand into his pocket, and pulled out four shells, and a little phial.

KING GEORGE . I am a watchman. On the Saturday morning, Matthews made a signal to me—I saw the prisoner, and stopped him, and asked him he had got any thing about him—he said, "No"—I observed him shifting his hands, as if he had got something—I searched him, and found four shells, and a phial on him—two in his coat-pocket, and two in his four shells-pocket—I asked him how he came by them—he said he bought then—I asked him who of—he said he bought them down the road, he did not know who of.

Prisoner. Q. Did not Matthews say, when you asked if he was sure I was the man who ran from him, that he was not certain? A. He said he was pretty well sure, but you were very much like the man, and he thought you were the man.
Prisoner. At Lambeth-street Office the watchman were quarrelling, and he did deny my being the man—it was not the witness, but a shorter man—there were four of them there.

THOMAS WELLS
re-examined. I know these shells—I am quite sure they are mine—I am positive they were in my dining-room the day before the robbery.

ANN DICKINSON
re-examined. I have the care of the room, and see the shells every morning—I am certain these are my master's.

Prisoner's Defence. On Friday night I went to the Pavilion, and being out late that night, could not get in at home, I thought I would take a walk down Stratford-road, and by the church I met a young man, who asked if I wanted to buy any shells—he wanted 18d. for the four—I bid him 1s., which he took.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Life.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1369.
JAMES SKIGGS and
WILLIAM SALES were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of April, 3 bushels of potatoes, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
John Scrafton Thompson.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM HOGG . I am a horse-patrol, at Stratford. On Sunday morn
ing, the 29th of April, about five o'clock, I was in the neighbourhood of Ilford, returning from the station, in company with Johnson—near Mr. Thompson's field there was a drove of cattle in the road—I saw two men come from the horse-road down to the footpath—each of them had a bag on his shoulder, which appeared to be full—they came from among the cattle on to the footpath—we followed one of the men towards Ilford—he went up an alley which leads to the Britannia beer-shop—we followed him about fifty yards up this alley—he put down the sack, and we went up to him—it was Skiggs—I asked what he had got—he wade no reply—I opened the sack, and found it contained potatoes—I asked how he came, by them—he said he had found them on the road—he was standing at the door of a house, which was open—I gave him into Davis's custody—in consequence of some conversation with Davis, I went with him and John
son to Sales' house—before we went into the house, we listened—I heard a conversation, but could make no sense of what was said—we knocked, and Sales opened the door—he was asked what he had made of

the bag of potatoes he had just brought in—he said he had no potatoes in his house; that he had brought none in, and had not been out of his house from the time he went to bed the night previous—this was about half-past five o'clock—we found a bag in a cupboard in the lower part of the house, similar to what I had seen the men carrying, and it contained potatoes—I cannot speak to Sales being one of the men I saw on the road.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. The men came from the cattle? A. Yes—I could not see them till they came on the footpath, near Mr. Thompson's field—when I first saw them they were just coming from the road to the footpath.

DAVID JOHNSON . I was with Hogg—I saw two men, each with a sack on his back—they appeared to me to be crossing from a gap in Mr. Thomp
son's fence on to the footpath on the other side—there was clamp of potatoes about 100 yards from the gap—there was a field between that and the road—I observed the impressions of two persons coming through that gap, but the mould being loose, I could not ascertain the measure of the marks—I went to Sales's house—before I went in I listened, and heard some con
versation between a man and a woman.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not Sales say that a person of the name of Richard somebody had brought the sack there? A. He said then that he had no sack in the house—he said next day that a man had brought it, and went out over the pales the back way—I found no man but Sales there.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What did you hear? A. A man said, "If it had not been for the b—patrols"—I then knocked, and Sales opened the door—I said, "Where are these potatoes?"—he said, "I have got no po
tatoes in my house"—he opened the back-door—I said, "No, I shall look into this cupboard," and there was the sack of potatoes—they were wet and warm, as if they had just come from the clamp.

SAMUEL DAVIS . I am a constable. I took Skiggs to the cage—I had reason to suspect who the other man was, and directed the officers to Sales—I heard him say something about the b—patrols, but I could not make out what—we went in, and Hogg asked for the potatoes—he said he had none in the house, but we found them in the cupboard, in a sack, and some were in a basket—they appeared the same sort as those in Mr. Thompson's clamp.

GABRIEL BARTHOLOMEW PAINE . I have been a farmer—I am looker to Mr. John Scrafton Thompson. I know his clamp of potatoes very well—on Saturday night, the 28th of April, it was safe, and next morning it had been broken into—I observed the gap in the fence—I have examined the two bags of potatoes that were found—I have no doubt they are the same as had been in Mr. Thompson's clamp.

SKIGGS*—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined One Year.

SALES*—
GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1370.
JOHN GILSON and
EDWARD GILSON were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March, 115lbs. weight of lead, value 20s., the goods of
Henry Gunson, and fixed to a building.

HENRY GUNSON . I live at West Ham. On the 25th of March I saw the lead safe on my summer-house, and on the 28th I missed it—I have compared this lead with the place it was taken from, and it corresponds in every respect—(looking at it.)
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you compare it since you

were before the Magistrate? A. No, before—I believe I told the Magis
trate I had done so, but I am not certain—I identified it.

PETER HILL . I am a gardener. About six o'clock in the morning of at 28th of March, I met the two prisoners coming up the side of the field—they had these two rolls of lead—each of them had one under his arm—I asked where they got it from—they said from their uncle—they left the lead in the road, right opposite Mr. Gunson's lodge, and walked away—I am sure the prisoners are the persons.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you known them before? A. I had seen them—I did not know them by name—I never spoke to them, or knew where they lived—I had seen them in a gentleman's garden, where I used to work—they got over the fence after the apples.
JOHN ELSON . I am a constable of Plaistow. I compared this lead with the summer-house, and it corresponded exactly.
WILLIAM GIBLING . I took the prisoner on the 26th of April. One was in prison then.

JOHN GIBSON*—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

EDWARD GIBSON*—
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years.

1371.
FREDERICK NEWTON and
CHARLES ESCOTT were in
dicted for
stealing,, on the 28th of April, 1 coat, value 1l.; 1 parasol, value 1l.; and 1 pair of gloves, value 6d.; the goods of
John Ingram Batten.

JOHN INGRAM BATTEN . I live in Bexley-place, Greenwich. This coat and parasol were safe on my premises on the morning of the 28th of April—I missed them about half-past ten o'clock—my house lies back from the road—the street-door was left open, but there is an iron railing in front of the house.

JANE HORN . I am in the service of Mrs. Kingsford, who lives at Bex
ley-house, opposite Bexley-place. On the 28th of April, I saw the prisoners near Mr. Batten's house—I saw Newton go in at the next gate, step over the chains, enter Mr. Batten's house, and come out with a coat and a parasol—he joined Escott, and they both walked off together—Escott had been walking up and down watching.

RICHARD LILLYWHITE . I am an officer. I received information, and followed the prisoners—I took them half a mile from the prosecutor's house—Newton had the parasol, and the gloves were in his pocket—I ap
prehended Escott as he was endeavouring to sell the coat at a pawn
broker's.
(Property product and sworn to.)
(Escott received a good character.)

NEWTON—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

ESCOTT—
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Three Months.

1372.
JOHN CHARLTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of April, 1 watch, value 5l., the goods of
Elizabeth Sinnock Bennett, his mis
tress.

JOHN BENNETT . I am a watchmaker and jeweller, and live in Stock
well-street,

Greenwich, with my mother, Elizabeth Sinnock Bennett. A gold watch belonging to Mr. Flower, of Lea, was left in my mother's care to be repaired—it was put in the workshop till it should be applied for—the officer afterwards produced it—this is the same watch—(looking at it.)

JAMES WHISKARD . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Bishopsgate-street. On the afternoon of the 21st of April, the prisoner brought this watch to pledge—I asked him whose it was—he said his own—I asked him where he got it from—he said his father gave it to him—I said, "Where does he live?"—he said, "No. 16, Worship-street"—I could see by his manner he had not got possession of the watch as he should have done, and I called in a policeman, and sent him to where he said his father lived—he brought him back, and said it was all wrong.

JAMES HALL (City police-constable 14.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody at Mr. Whiskard's shop—he said he wanted to go to No. 16, Worship-street, where his father lived—I took him there, and showed him the house—I said, "Shall I knock at the door, is this the house?"—he said, "No"—I looked at him, and he began to cry—I said, "Is it all wrong?"—he said, "Yes, sir"—I took him back to Mr. Whiskard's, and at the station-house I found on him a cheque for 21l., a silver watch, and a metal watch, which I produce, and a few shillings.

WILLIAM HOUGH . I am a watchmaker in Mrs. Bennett's employ. This gold watch is hers—it was in her care to repair—the prisoner was our er
rand boy, and was left in the workshop at different times while we were absent—he was intrusted with this silver watch to bring up to town—I know the metal watch to be Mrs. Bennett's property, but when it was taken I cannot say.

JOHN BENNETT
re-examined. He was one of two errand boys—the other is in prison now for robbing us—they had both been in the house some time together.

Prisoner. I acknowledge taking the gold watch—I took it on the sa
turday morning that I was taken into custody—I was sent to Tottenham to pay a cheque, and not having any money with me I took the watch to pawn to pay for my coach-hire—I meant to take it out again on the Mon
day, and replace it. Witness. He was supplied with 11s. to pay his expenses, and that was taken from his pocket—he was intrusted to take the cheque to Tottenham—he had still got that about him.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined One Year.

1373.
HENRY KNIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of April, 1 half-crown, 7 shillings, 6 sixpences, and 3 fourpenny pieces, the monies of
William Covell, his master.

JAMES COVELL . I am the son of William Covell, a butcher, in Broad
way, Deptford. The prisoner was in his employ—in consequence of sus
picions I entertained on the 17th of April, I marked one half-crown, seven shillings, six sixpences, and three fourpenny pieces, and put them into the till—I examined the till the following morning, and found the marked money still there—I then put it into a purse into a desk in the shop, and af
terwards missed the money from the desk, but not the purse—I sent for a policeman—the prisoner was searched—one marked shilling was found on him, and another the policeman got from the maid servant—I had left the key of the desk on the mantel-shelf in the parlour, and the desk was in the shop.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is your father here to-day? A. No—this prosecution is with his consent—quite so—he has not said he had rather have paid 402. than the prisoner should be prosecuted—he said he would rather pay 40l. than he should be transported—I have not had any particular quarrel with the prisoner—I do not remember that I quarrelled with him the day he was taken into custody—I will not swear I did not—it was on Thursday evening, the 26th, he was apprehended—I had put the marked money into the desk on the Wednesday week previous—it was always the custom to leave the key of that desk on the mantel-shelf when I went to work, before my father was up—it was not left unlocked—the money re
mained untouched for a week—all the family and the maid servant had access to the room where the key was—I was not playing at a game called cock-shy with the prisoner on the day he was taken—I saw him and George Munns playing at it in my father's yard—I do not remember quarrelling with him then—I did not play with him at all that day—I did the day before—at least I was playing with Munns, and he wished to play with us—cock-shy is a stick stuck in the ground with a piece of money on the top of it to throw at—I see you understand it—I had some shillings the day before, but none passed between us—I changed some sixpences with him, but nothing else—I do not think any passed between Munns and me—my father desired me to send for a policeman—he was at home at the time.

Q. Had you paid the prisoner any silver between the time of your de
positing the money in the desk, and your causing him to be taken into custody? A. Yes, 11s. 6d.—most of that was in sixpences and four-penny pieces—I cannot tell what the rest was—I cannot say whether there were any shillings—I paid it him on the Sunday morning previous to his being taken—I will swear I did not pay him as many as eleven shillings—I had not marked any other money before—it was about eleven o'clock on Thursday night, that I found the marked money gone from the desk—it was about one o'clock in the afternoon that the prisoner and Munns were playing at cock-shy—the prisoner lost two shillings to me the day before, and two shillings to Munns—he continued to play with Munns and I left them—I did not go after that, and play at skittles at the Druid's Head—I had been there on the Monday before with Munns, and the prisoner wished to go to stick up the skittles—I scarcely ever played before, and should not then had it not been for my cousin Munns being in town—I am not in the habit of frequenting skittle-grounds—I will swear I did not play at cock-shy with the prisoner on the Thursday that he was taken—I wished the prisoner to go about his business, because I wished the business to be done—there were some sheep to be killed, and I wished him to go and do it—(my father was at home at the time)—he said he wished to have a game first—I told him to go and kill the sheep—nothing else passed—we did not quarrel—I think they left off playing in my presence—it was about three o'clock in the afternoon—not so late as five or six o'clock—the prisoner came to live with my father through a friend—he was not engaged because I was in the habit of playing at skittles and cock-shy, and would not attend to the business.

ELIZABETH HOATH . I am in the prosecutor's service. The prisoner borrowed eighteen-pence of me about two months ago, and on the 26th of April he paid me one shilling of it back—he said, he had not got a six
pence—I put the shilling into my pocket, and gave it to the officer
afterwards, having first marked it—the prisoner paid it me of his own accord—I did not ask for it.

JOHN ROSCOE (police-constable R 119.) I searched the prisoner and found a marked shilling in his trowsers pocket—I showed it to James Covill, and he said it was a shilling which he had marked—I also received another marked shilling from Hoath, and she marked it in my presence—these are them.
Cross-examined. Q. Who sent for you? A. One of Mr. Covill's sons, but not James—he gave the prisoner in charge—he said he supposed he had been robbing the desk of the marked money.

JAMES COVILL
re-examined. A marked shilling was also found on Munns—these are two of the shillings I marked—the money I paid him on the Sunday I got from a different desk.

GEORGE MUNNS . I had a marked shilling among my other money—I do not know how I got it—I had received a shilling from the prisoner in the course of Thursday—I won 1s. of him—there was no quarrel between my cousin and the prisoner in my presence.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been playing with your cousin as well as the prisoner? A. Not that day—I did the day before—I had been in town about a week—I do not know bow many times we played at this game—we had nothing else to do to amuse ourselves—I had not won any money of my cousin, nor he of me—I cannot say whether he lost any
thing to the prisoner—we took turns in putting the money on the sticks—I think my cousin put sixpence on—I played at skittles once at the Druid's Head with my cousin—I do not remember who won there—I was at one other place with the prisoner—I never had more than 1s. from the prisoner—I never had any money from my cousin on any occasion—I do not re
member whether I knocked any money off which he put on the stick.
NOT GUILTY .

1374.
ELIZABETH EDDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of April, 1 shawl, value 2s. 6d.; 3 shillings, 4 pence, and 16 halfpence; the goods and monies of
Mary Mahoney; and that she had been before con
victed of felony.

MARY MAHONEY . I am a widow, and live in Harding-lane, Woolwich. On the 9th of April I went up stairs to put my child to bed, and left my shawl and this money down in my room—the prisoner lives next door to me—I came down in ten minutes, and my shawl and money were gone—it was between six and seven o'clock in the evening—this is my shawl, I am certain—(looking at it.)
Prisoner. Q. Did you not lend me a shawl that morning? A. No, I never had any thing to do with you—I had only lived there seven days.
FRANCIS CHANDLER . I am shopman to Mr. Davis, a pawnbroker at Woolwich. On the evening of the 19th of April, Millar pawned this shawl with me.

PHILIP MILLAR . I am a baker. I was at the Duchess of Wellington public-house—the prisoner called me outside, and asked if I would take the shawl and pawn it—I said yes, and did so—she gave it to me off her shoulders.

Prisoner's Defence. In the morning I asked the prosecutrix to lend me a shawl, to go down the town, which she did; and when I came home, she said she wanted it, and I might have the other if I liked—in the even
ing I asked that young man to get 9d. on it, and I would fetch it out in the morning; and when I was apprehended I told them I would fetch it—I had pawned it for 9d.
CHARLES STEWART WARDEN . I am superintendent of the watch at Woolwich. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction of felony from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the woman.

GUILTY . Aged 49.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1375.
FRANCES HOPKINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of April, 1 shift, value 2s.; 1 night-gown, value 2s.; 1 sheet, value 2s.; 1 shawl, value 2s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 pair of stockings, value 6d.; the goods of
Richard Gilbert, her master.

SARAH GILBERT . I am the wife of Richard Gilbert, and live in the Lewisham-road, in the parish of Deptford. The prisoner was in my ser
vice—she left us on the morning of the 5th of April, and I missed the articles stated in the indictment, which are here,—they are ours—the was tent by the parish to nurse me.

Prisoner. You lent me the things, or I never should have taken them—you wanted me to come—I was very ill, and I had not time to bring my own clothes—you said you would lend me the things. Witness. On my oath, it is not true.
Prisoner. It was a roguish business of mine, certainly; but I have been used to good service, and had not she been a rogue of a mistreat I never should have run away.

JOHN DYKE . I am a policeman. I was on duty on this morning, and saw the prisoner, about ten or eleven o'clock, in Trafalgar-row, Greenwich, with this parcel in her hand—I took it from her—it was part of the pro
perty stolen.

GUILTY .* Aged 32.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1376.
CHARLOTTE DEBNAM was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of May, 5 pillows, value 10s.; 4 blankets, value 1l. 3s.; 10 yards of car
pet, value 55.; 1 table-cloth, value 2s.; 1 bolster, value 2s.; 1 wine-glass, value 6d.; and I saw, value 2s.; the goods of
Samuel Tunnicliff.

ELIZABETH TUNNICLIFF . I am the wife of Samuel Tunnicliff—he keeps a public-house at Deptford. The prisoner lodged at my house—I missed the articles named in the indictment, some of which are here—when she went away some duplicates were found, which I gave to the officer.
BENJAMIN HASELDINE . I am a pawnbroker. I produce the property—I cannot tell who pawned it, but I have the corresponding duplicates to those produced.
BENJAMIN LOVELL . I took the prisoner into custody, and told her the charge—she said she intended to pay Mr. Tunnicliff, and get the things out.

Prisoner's Defence. I had no felonious intention—the prosecutrix com
promised the matter by taking 10s., and retained the duplicates in her possession—my husband paid her the 10s., and told her to make her elec
tion either to prosecute or take part of the money.

ELIZABETH TUNNICLIFF
re-examined. It is not so—she owed me 5l. for rent, and I took the 10s. for that—I gave the husband a receipt for it—I found the duplicates under the bed after she was gone.

GUILTY . Aged 41.—
Confined Six Months.
Before Mr. Justice Park.

1377.
MARY ANN LEAVER was indicted
for the wilful murder of a certain female child.

(The prisoner had been delivered of an illegitimate child, which was dis
covered in the privy of her mother's house. Upon the evidence of Mr. Thomas Light, surgeon, of Woolwich, there was no proof of its having been born alive. The evidence being of a nature unfit for publication, is omitted.)
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1378.
JOHN KNOTT was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of April 1 cloak, value 18s.; and 1 shawl, value 2s.; the goods of
William Smith: and 1 cloak, value 10s.; the goods of
Mary Griffiths.

WILLIAM SMITH . I was on a visit at Mr. Mason's, at Deptford. On the 25th of April an alarm was given by my wife's sister that the window was open—I ran out, and on going down Grove-street I saw two young met—I made towards them—to the best of my belief the prisoner was one of them—they divided—one came towards me without a bundle—the pri
soner went on with the bundle—I walked after him—he walked fast, I began to run—he dropped the bundle and ran on—a man took him—I picked up the bundle, and it contained these two cloaks and the shawl—two of them are my wife's—I will not be positive the prisoner is the lad who dropped the bundle, but I believe he is.
GEORGE GRIFFITHS . I live at Deptford. I saw the prosecutor running after the prisoner, crying "Stop thief,"—he dropped this bundle close by me—I am certain he is the person.
FRANCIS WALL . I saw the prisoner running towards the Plough-bridge—he ran and concealed himself under the palings.
Prisoner's Defence. He did not see me running. I did not have the bundle at all—the witness said he could not swear to me at all.

GEORGE GRIFFITHS
re-examined. I stared in his face—I saw the pro
secutor running—the prisoner walked gently past me till he got four or five yards, and then ran off directly.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

1379.
SAMUEL SHORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of April, 1 pair of boots, value 8s. 6d., the goods of
James Gilham.

JOHN PILGRIM . I am shopman to Mr. James Gilham, a boot and shoe
maker at Greenwich. On the evening of the 11th of April I ran out of the shop, being alarmed, and saw the prisoner going round the street—I went up to him—he threw the boots down—these are them—they are my master's, and they had been in the shop just before.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.

1380.
CHARLES CHAPMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of April, 1 watch-ribbon, value 1s.; 1 seal, value 6d.; 1 watch-key, value 6d.; and 2 split-rings, value 6d.; the goods of
Samuel Ind, from his person.

SAMUEL IND . I live in Devonshire-terrace, Devonshire-street, St. Dunstan's. On the 28th of April I was crossing Greenwich-park towards Blackheath—the prisoner came up to me and asked the time—I said, "Twenty-five minutes to one"—I had a watch with a ribbon and key—I took it out to look, and I put it into my fob—he turned round twice—I suspected he meant no good, and I turned to the road—he turned and said again, "What time is it?"—I told him again, and he snatched at my guard—it broke, and then he snatched at my ribbon, and took it with the key, and two rings—he went towards the gate of the park—I followed him and had him taken, and they were found on him.
AARON OUTRED (police-constable R 128.) I heard the cry of "Stop thief"—I went up and took the prisoner—I found a ribbon, a key, and two rings in his pocket, which the prosecutor claimed.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Ten Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1381.
RICHARD FOWLER was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of April, 3 razors, value 5s.; and 1 front of hair, value 1s.; the goods of
William Moore.

WILLIAM MOORE . I am a hair-dresser. On the 30th of April the prisoner came to me, with another man, who wanted his hair cut, and while I was doing it the prisoner was very busy about the shop, looking about—the other man got up, with his hair half cut, and said, "I won't have any more of this;" and they both went out without paying me—about three minutes after they were gone I missed three razors and a hair front—these are them—(looking at them.)
Prisoner. Q. Which man went out first? A. You went out first—I asked you to sit down, but you would not—you went to the glass and combed your hair out—you have come into my shop before you washed.
GEORGE HOGG . Between five and six o'clock, in the evening of the 30th of April, I was in the tap-room of the King's Arms, and bought these two razors of the prisoner.
Prisoner. Q. Was there not another man with me? A. There was not.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

1382.
JOHN GARDINER was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of April, 4lbs. weight of ham, value 1s.; part of a dead fowl, value 1s.; part of a loaf, value 1d.; and six plates, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Allan M'kenzie.

HANNAH PETERSFIELD . I live at Woolwich, in the service of Allan M'Kenzie. On the 18th of April I saw this property safe at half-past ten o'clock in the larder, and it was afterwards found on the prisoner.
GEORGE RUDDICK (police-constable R 170.) I took the prisoner at half-past one o'clock in the morning had this property on him.
Prisoner. I bought them of a sailor. Witness. He told me his uncle gave it him.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1383.
JOSEPH WHEELER was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of April, 1 shirt, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Nicholas Orchard.

WILLIAM ROE ORCHARD . I am the son of Nicholas Orchard, an eating-house keeper, in London-street, Greenwich. The prisoner was in it my father's employ—he used to help in the kitchen—on the 11th of April, I heard my father discharge him as I was cleaning myself—the prisoner went into the bed-room to take his things about half-past two o'clock, and directly after he was gone I missed a shirt of my father's, which had been on the bed—I saw it again a fortnight or three weeks after, at the office with the prisoner—this is the shirt.
Prisoner. It was five o'clock when I left the house, and my master saw what clothes I had—he searched me, and it was not about me.
JOHN DAWSON . I am a pawnbroker at Greenwich. I took in this shirt of the prisoner on the 11th of April, in the name of John Harris.
Prisoner. I was not in his house—I do not know where he lives. Witness. I am sure he is the person.
GUILTY . Aged 20.

1384.
JOSEPH WHEELER was again indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of April, 1 coat, value 10s.; the goods of
John Davis.
JOHN DAVIS . I am a servant at a public-house at Greenwich. I lost my coat from an outbuilding in the yard, where we clean the boots and knives, on Friday the 19th of April—this is it.
JOSEPH ABATHY . I am a pawnbroker at Blackheath-hill. I took in this coat of the prisoner on the 19th of April, in the name of Joseph Wheeler, for 5s.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the coat in the fair for 1s. 6d.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1385.
JOHN WILKINS and
JAMES PAYNE were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 5s.; the goods of
Joseph Groves, from his person.

JOSEPH GROVES . On the 16th of April I was at Greenwich-fair. I had a handkerchief in my coat-pocket—I did not miss it till the policeman told me of it—I then followed, and saw him take it from the breeches of one of the prisoners—this is it.

BENJAMIN SAMUEL BLABEN (police-constable A 56.) About half-past five o'clock on the 16th of April, I saw the two prisoners in Greenwich-fair, trying several persons' pockets—they were together, and sometimes arm
in-arm in front of Richardson's show—they were lifting up pockets and putting their hands in—when they got to the prosecutor, Payne took a silk handkerchief from his pocket, and passed it to Wilkins, who was covering him as he did it—I told the prosecutor and took Payne—Brooks took Wilkins.
JAMES BROOKS (police-constable L 118.) I took the handkerchief from Wilkins' breeches—what Blaben has said is true.
Wilkins' Defence. I was standing in front of the show when some person, I do not know who, thrust a handkerchief into my hand, and I thrust it into my button-hole, having no pockets.
(The prisoners received excellent characters.)

WILKINS—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

PAYNE—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

Recommended to mercy—
Confined Three Months .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1386.
CHARLES MARTIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of April, one handkerchief, value 6d.; the goods of
Robert Chapman, from his person.

ROBERT CHAPMAN . I am a bricklayer, and live in Edward's-lane, Deptford. I was at Greenwich-fair on the 18th of April, about eleven clock, looking at one of the shows—a policeman touched me, and said something—I missed my handkerchief—this is it—(looking at it.)

ROBERT CLARKE (police-constable R 167.) On the 18th of April I saw a prisoner between nine and ten o'clock, trying several people's pockets—I went behind the prosecutor, and stood there a few minutes, and then left him—I took him, and he had this handkerchief in his hand—on searching. him, I found three other handkerchiefs.
Prisoner. Two of the policemen came and took me out of the crowd, and said, "What do you do with this handkerchief?" but I had never seen—it never was in my hand. Witness. I took it from his hand.
JAMES WEBB (police-constable V 134.) I was there, and saw this. handkerchief in the prisoner's hand—I told the prosecutor of it.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year.

1387.
MARTHA WEARING was indicted
for embezzlement.

REV. JOHN SMALLMAN MASTERS . I live at Greenwich—the pri
soner was employed as collectress to the Greenwich Provident Society, of which I am treasurer—myself and others subscribed to the society—the prisoner was servant to me and the society in 1836—it was her duty to receive deposits, and pay them to me—if she received 1s. on the 10th of April, 1838, she has not paid it to me.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was there any document in writing, of the society and the persons who formed the subscribers and trustees? A. Yes; but I have it not with me—the prisoner is charged with receiving 2s. from Lygo in April last year—the Provident Society was dissolved in December, 1836, previous to the receipt of this shilling—the prisoner was not a servant of the society after December, 1836—in August, 1837, she asked me for her salary as collectress of the society—I laughed at her, and told her she was no servant of the society—I believe she told me then that not knowing the society was dissolved in December, she had collected some monies, and I told her to return them to the parties.
NOT GUILTY .

1388.
MARTHA WEARING was again indicted
for obtaining money by false pretences.

REV. JOHN SMALLMAN MASTERS . I was treasurer to the Provident Society, to which others subscribed up to December, 1836—it was then dissolved—the prisoner was our servant from the 17th of May, 1836, to the end of December—she was to receive monies and collect subscriptions during that period—she had not a written authority, but a verbal authority, but not after 1836—the society was at an end then—I do not know whether she knew that it was dissolved—she had no notice that she was discharged from me—we took it for granted that she knew it was dissolved—in Au
gust she applied to me for her salary, and said she had received some monies,—I
told her she had no right to receive them, and to take them back again to the parties.
NOT GUILTY .

1389.
EDWARD GEORGE was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MESSRS. BODKIN and ESPINASSE conducted the Prosecution.

JOSEPH WOOD . I am thirteen years old. I live in Rhode-street Greenwich, with Allen, a police-constable—on the 7th of April I saw the prisoner between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, in Rhode-street—he asked me to go into Mr. Moore's shop, to get him a quarter of an ounce of tobacco, and he gave me a sixpence to pay for it—I got the tobaca, and gave Mrs. Moore the sixpence—she gave me change—I did not see where she put the sixpence—I went to the prisoner and gave him the change, and he ran away—he had promised me a halfpenny for my trouble before I went in, but he did not give it me.
Prisoner. Q. Was there any body with me? A. No—I gave you 5 1/4 d. change.

AMELIA MOORE . My husband's name is George Moore. He is a beer-seller in Rhode-street, Greenwich—I saw Wood on the 7th of April, at near nine o'clock in the evening—I knew him before—he came for a quarter of an ounce of tobacco—it came to 3/4 d.—he gave me a 6d.—I gave him change—I took the sixpence up, and found it was bad—I gave it to my husband to examine, and he went out with it to see for the little boy—I got the sixpence from my husband, and put it on a shelf by itself—I afterwards marked it, and gave it to the policeman.

GEORGE MOORE . I am the husband of Amelia Moore. I received a sixpence from her on the 7th of April, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening—I looked at it, and said it was a bad one—I went to the uncle of Joseph Wood, and I gave the sixpence to one Fisher—he gave it me back, and I gave it my wife—she put it on a shelf—nobody but me my wife has access to that shelf.
Prisoner. Q. You said you took it to the boy's mother? A. No, he has no mother—it was not out of my hand.

MARY ANN BEDWELL . I am the daughter of James Bed well; he lives in Thames-street, Greenwich. I saw the prisoner on the 10th of April—he asked me where, they sold tobacco—I told him, in Mr. Barnes's shop—he said that would not do—he then gave me a sixpence, and told me to go and get a pennyworth of tobacco—I went to Mr. Home's shop, and asked for a pennyworth of tobacco—I got it, and gave the sixpence which the prisoner gave me—I got the change, and I went back to the prisoner—I gave him the change and the tobacco—he gave me another sixpence to get a penny candle—he did not tell me where to go—I went to Mr. Waller's, and got a candle, and gave the sixpence for it, which he gave me—I got the change and the candle—I gave the change to the prisoner—he gave me the candle for my trouble.
Prisoner. The woman said she had not served anybody, and she showed the policeman the sixpences she had—he said there was not one bad.

WILLIAM THOMAS HORNE . My father's name is John Home; he lives in Thames-street, Greenwich. On Tuesday evening, the 10th of April, I saw the prisoner between eight and nine o'clock, in Thames-street—he asked me to go for an egg for him—he gave me a bad sixpence—I paid
that sixpence at Mrs. Waller's—she gave me 5 1/4 d. which I gave to the prisoner, and he went away.
Prisoner. Q. When you went into that shop, Mrs. Waller asked you who sent you with the sixpence, and you said your mother? A. Yes—told me to say it was for my mother.

MARY WALLER . I am the wife of Jonathan Sherman Waller, a chand
ler and shoemaker, in Thames-street, Greenwich. On the 10th of April, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, Mary Ann Bedwell came for a penny candle—she paid me a sixpence, and I gave her 5d. change—I put the sixpence on the shelf—there was nothing with it—in two or three minutes afterwards, Home came for a penny egg—I said I had not got one—I gave him a three-farthing one—he paid for it with a sixpence—I gave him 5 1/4 d. change—I sent my little girl to fetch her father, and gave him both the sixpences together.

JONATHAN SHERMAN WALLER . On the 10th of April, I received two sixpences from my wife, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening—I sent one double, and went up the street—I told the policeman, there were some men passing bad money—I went back to my shop with him, and marked the sixpences, and gave them to him.

THOMAS HICKLINO (police-constable R 118.) I received two sixpences from Mr. Jonathan Sherman Waller—these are them—(producing them)—I received one sixpence from Mrs. Moore—this is it—(producing another)—I took the prisoner into custody—I found on him one farthing—that is all.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint—these three sixpences are all counterfeit, and two of them were cast in the tame mould—the other is not.

Prisoner's Defence. I was at home at the time the children swear I gave them the sixpences—I buy and tell fish about the town—when the policeman came to me, I went with him—the Inspector would not book the charge—he told me to come next morning, and the policeman came to me, and I went—it is not likely that I should go about the town, where I get my living, and pass bad money.

GUILTY .*—Aged 21.
Confined Two Years.
Before Mr. Recorder.

1390.
WILLIAM ELLIS and
WILLIAM CALLY were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
Charles Graham Marshall, from his person.

GEORGE THORNTON (police-constable E 91.) On the 16th of April, I was on duty in Greenwich fair—I saw the prisoners, about six o'clock in the evening, trying several gentlemen's pockets—I was with another con
stable—I saw Cally take from the prosecutor this silk handkerchief, and hand it to Ellis—he was about putting it into his breast, when Dowsing took him, and I took Cally—I spoke to the prosecutor, who identified it—he stated before the Magistrate that his name was Charles Graham Mar
shall, and signed the charge as such—he goes by that name at his lodging—he signed his name on the sheet, "Charles Graham Marshall," and answered to that name—I searched Cally at the station-house, and found another handkerchief round his leg, and a pair of gloves in his pocket—I called at the prosecutor's lodgings, and find he is gone to France, and not expected to return for three years.
THOMAS DOWSING . I searched the prisoner Ellis, and found on him a fish-hook, with which they generally take handkerchiefs, and a snuff-box some cigars, and a lucifer match-box."
Ellis's Defence. It is my mother's box—I am in Bishopsgate work ho se—she sent me out to get some snuff—I put the box into my pocket and went to the fair.
(Cally received a good character.)

ELLIS—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

CALLY—
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Confined Three Months.

1391.
CHARLES READ was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th April, 1 spoon, value 10s., the goods of
William Carroll, his master.

WILLIAM CARROLL . I am a surgeon, and live in Dean's-row, Walworth The prisoner was my footman—he came into my service on the 5th April—on the 9th of May I saw him in custody at the office, and spoon was produced, which belonged to me—the prisoner had the opportu
nity of taking it.

FREDERICK JOHN WOOD . I am shopman to Mr. Rosier, a pawnbroker I produce a table-spoon, which was pawned on the 16th of April—I be
lieve the prisoner to be the person, but I cannot swear positively to Him—this is the duplicate I gave to the person who pledged it.

JOHN RAYHILL . I took the prisoner into custody, offering to sell broken dessert fork to a pawnbroker—I took him to the station—he said it belonged to his aunt, at Bermondsey—I afterwards found he lived at the prosecutor's—I went there, and searched a box, which had the key in it and found in it the duplicate of the spoon pawned at Rosier's on the 16th of April.

MR. CARROLL re-examined. The box the officer searched belonged to the prisoner—it was in the back kitchen—he went out with medicine that day, and was detained at a pawnbroker's, with the broken fork—this is my spoon—(looking at it.)
Prisoner. I kept the duplicate in my box, because I was going to take it out again.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Justice Park.

1392.
THOMAS BONNER was indicted
for killing and slaying
Felix Charles.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS WINCH . I live at No. 44, Weymouth-street, and am a baker. On the evening of the 22nd of January I was at the Constitution public-house, and saw the deceased Felix Charles, with a man named Harwood—they came into the tap-room, and were served with a pot of beer—soon after
wards the prisoner, who is the landlord, came into the tap-room, and asked Harwood to sit down, as he was standing before the fire—he said he was very cold, and said, "I shall sit down presently, but is not this a tap-room?"—the

prisoner said, "If you do not sit down, you shall go out"—Harwoodsaid, "No, you won't"—Bonner said, "I shall" and took him by the collar, and took him out of the tap-room—they had a scuffle—they went out together—the deceased got up, and followed them out—that was all he did—all three came into the tap-room, after being out three or four minutes, and were quite, friendly, both the deceased, the prisoner, and Harwood—when they came back, the deceased said to Bonner, "Why do you be so passionate, Mr. Bonner?"—that was about a minute or two after they came in—he said, "Why don't you be of a mild temper, like me?"—he said, "Let us be comfortable, Mr. Bonner; we don't come here to make a piece of work, we came to be comfortable, and have a pot of porter; let us shake hands toge
ther," and they shook hands—the pot of beer had come in before the de
ceased sat down—after they had sat down three or four minutes the de
ceased said, "Bonner, if you had served me as you served that man, you should have gone down"—the deceased had a pot of beer in his hand, and the prisoner snatched it from his hand, and said, "Would you, by G—?" and threw the rest of the beer in his face—the deceased rose up, and pushed him away from him, and Bonner struck him with the pot on the head—the deceased shoved him away, and the prisoner directly struck him on the head with the pot—the push the deceased gave was not violent—he had his at off when he got the blow with the pot—the prisoner's wife came in, and got between them—the deceased was forcing to get at him, and the prisoner kept repeatedly hitting him with the pot, three or four times—I am sure he hit him four times.

COURT. Q. Before they shook hands, did not the prisoner say, "I am rather passionate, but let it all drop?" A. I did not hear that—I am sure of that—I did not hear the words, "Let it all drop"—I never heard him say so.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. May that expression have taken place, and you forget it? A. Yes, it is a good while ago—he may have said so—after the prisoner struck the deceased, he fell from the last blow—the deceased sent for the doctor—I had not drank anything myself that night—the man that came in with the deceased (Harwood) went for the doctor—nobody sent for him but the deceased—he came and cut the deceased's hair off—he came in it; or six minutes after the blow was struck—he lives next door—the de
ceased said to him, "Now, do what is necessary, and you shall be paid for it; you have no occasion to be afraid, you will be paid for what you do;" and the doctor said, "You go home and get a poultice, and come to me in the morning"—I cannot say how long he staid in the public-house, for I left myself about nine o'clock.
COURT. Q. When he shoved him away, he shoved him in the breast, did not he? A. Yes.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he get his head dressed at Guy's-hospital? A. I do not know—I do not remember his returning to the tap-room when his head was dressed—I was not there.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was these a journeyman baker's benefit—society held at this house? A. Yes, the deceased was not a member of the society at this time—he had not been turned out of the house for riotous conduct before this, that I know of—I have not learnt it from himself—I was not one of the society—Harwood was rather the worse for liquor—he was not sober—he was not at all noisy—the landlord put him out because he would not sit down—the deceased was quite sober—I will

swear that he was sober, to every appearance—he had not been drinking there—the landlord had not refused to let him have any beer—the landlord took Harwood out—he was followed by the deceased—they all three came in after that—the deceased did not say that if the old Irish b—r in
terfered with him, he would knock the old b—r's life out of him—I never saw Harwood and the deceased till they came into the room—I never heard the deceased strike the table with his fist, and say they were all a set of cowards to suffer the man to be turned out—I know the pot-boy brought in a pot of beer—I do not know whether that was unknown to the landlord or not—after they had shook hands, the deceased did not use violent lan
guage, and make a disturbance—Mr. Bonner did not come in a second time and desire the deceased, and his companions, to be quiet, and take hold of the pot of beer, and say, "You shall have no beer here"—nothing of the sort passed, that I heard—the prisoner did not struggle with the deceased for the pot of beer—the deceased did not square at the landlord till the beer was thrown in his face—he rose up, and pushed him, he then squared at him—the beer was not thrown over the deceased in the struggle of the landlord endeavouring to take away the beer, saying, he should have no more; it was owing to the words—the deceased did not strike Bonners blow over the right eye, to my knowledge—I will swear I did not see it—I saw no blow struck—I know there was more than one blow on the head of the man—I saw four.

Q. Did Page and Sherlock get between the prisoner and the deceased, to separate them? A. They were never in the room—the deceased never said he would smash their heads—he never saw them—the prisoner by Striking the deceased, struck the prisoner's wife with the pot—she had no blow from the deceased—I never heard that about three quarters of an how after this happened, the deceased went to the house with a club, and swore he would have the b—life of Mr. Bonner, and made every body give him 2s. 6d. each—I did not hear any witness depose to that effect before the Coroner—I was not in the room all the while—I do not belong to the society—I did not draw the brief for the prosecution—I gave my statement of the evidence to the attorney—I cannot tell who the attorney is—I stated before the Coroner that the deceased said to the doctor, "Do what is ne
cessary, and you shall be paid"—it was taken down in writing, and read over to me afterwards, before I signed the depositions—my deposition was read over to me, and that was in it.

COURT. Q. Do you mean to represent, solemnly, that you stated that, and heard it read out of the paper, or are you only sure you said it? A. I said it to the Coroner—I do not remember hearing it read.

THOMAS NEWSON . I am the pot-boy. I was in the Constitution on the 23rd of January—I saw the deceased, and Mr. Bonner, and Harwood—I was there when they came in—I took the beer to them—after that, Mr. Bonner came out of the parlour into the tap-room, and said to the deceased and Harwood, "What a noise you are making!"—the deceased said, "We are not," and Bonner said to Harwood, "If you do not sit down and be quiet, I shall turn you out"—he was standing up by the lire-place—Har
wood answered him, "Oh no, you won't"—Bonner said, "Yes, I will," and took him by the collar, and turned him out—they then came in again, and Mr. Bonner followed them, and the deceased said to Mr. Bonner, "What a curious tempered man you are! come, shake hands, and be friendly"—Bonner said, "If you will sit down and be quiet, I will"—the deceased sat down with a pot of beer in his hand, and before he drank, he

said to Bonner, "You put me out of your house once; if you had put me cut as you did my friend, I should have put you down"—Bonner said, "Would you, by G—d?"—he said, "Yes, I would"—Bonner caught the pot that was in his hands, and turned the beer over him, with his left hand he took the deceased by the collar, and struck him a blow on the top of his head—I do not recollect whether his hat was on or off—the deceased rose up, pushed his arm out, and struck Bonner in the eye; then Bonner struck him three or four times afterwards—the blow over the eye was a pretty violent one—I saw Bonner the next morning, and he had a black eye—he had no black eye before he received that blow from the deceased.

COURT. Q. How often did the prisoner strike him after he struck his eye? A. Four times—then Mrs. Bonner came into the room, got between them, stopped them, and got a black eye herself—I cannot say who gave her that—the deceased did not strike Bonner in the eye before Bonner struck him with the quart pot—I do not recollect saying before the Coroner that the deceased struck Bonner before he hit him with the quart pot.

Q. You named to the Coroner about being in the back part of the room? A. Yes, they asked me if I saw the deceased strike Bonner in the eye, and I said I did not see the blow given, but he put his arm out—I am not quite sure who struck first.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. There were a good many people in the room, I sup
pose? A. Yes, quite full—the deceased sent for the doctor—it was my master's doctor who came—I have seen him in the house before—after the deceased's head was dressed, I saw him in my master's house that night about nine or ten o'clock—I think about three quarters of an hour after his head was dressed—Mr. Page and Mrs. Bonner were there among others—three half-crowns were offered the deceased by Sherlock, the prisoner's son-in-law—he refused it at first, but finally took it—Mrs. Bonner was present at the time—she consented to his having the money—I do not know whether the de
ceased got any more money from any of the family afterwards—Harwood went for the doctor.

COURT. Q. The prisoner gave him brandy and water when he came back from the hospital? A. Mrs. Bonner did before he went to the hos
pital—he asked for brandy and water, saying he was faint—Mrs. Bonner offered him any thing he could wish for.

Cross-examined. Q. Was Page spending the evening at the house that night? A. Yes, and Mr. Wetheridge and Sherlock, the prisoner's son-in-law—I do not know when Harwood came in—the deceased had been drinking—when he came back he had a stick in his hand—I did not hear him say he had come to have Bonner's life—I am not sure he did not say it—they were in the bar, and I was in the tap-room, and came out at times—Harwood, and the deceased, and the rest of the bakers were not particularly noisy that night—they like to have a song themselves—I do not know how often Bonner had gone to them to re
quest them to be quiet—he had only been once before he turned out Harwood—as soon as he turned him out the deceased went and fetched him back—at that time the deceased had been drinking, Bonner said, "If you will be quiet and peaceable, you may remain where you are"—Bonner then returned to his room to his friends—he did not come to the room a third time, to require them to be quiet—I paid for the beer which the deceased had, myself, at the bar, and took it into the room—the beer was upset, and he would not pay for it, and I had the

money back again from Mrs. Bonner—I heard the deceased say, after this had happened, if the little Irish b—r interfered with him he would knock his old b—y life out of him—he struck the table with his fist, and said they were all a set of b—y cowards to suffer the man to be turned out—Winch was present at that time—I did not see the deceased square at Mr. Bonner—I understood he was twenty-seven years of age—he was fine, strong young man.

WILLIAM RANDALL . I am a surgeon. I usually attend Mr. Bonner's family—I live next door to them—I was sent for to the deceased—he seemed quite in possession of himself—his head was bleeding—I took the hair off, clearly to see the state of the wound—the scalp was divided, not so deep as the bone—blood was flowing in considerable quantities from the wound, and it appeared to be bruised as well as divided—there were no marks of more than one blow—as there was but one wound, I think it must have been only one blow—I directed him to get his head poulticed—it did not strike me as at all dangerous at the time.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not consider the wound of any serious character then? A. I did not—I was told to attend him the next day, and see him as often as was necessary, and Mr. Bonner would satisfy me for any expenses that would occur—I told him to come to me the next morning—he did not come—I went to him to Guy's Hospital, at the de
sire of Mr. Bonner, but I could not interfere there—I did not see him lat
terly—he was never let out of the hospital—I believe, for a considerable time, he was doing well, and was expected shortly to recover.

JOHN COALES . I was an assistant to Mr. Key, a surgeon, at Guy's Hospital, at the time the accident happened. I remember the deceased coming there about the middle of the day on the 23rd, as an inmate—he remained there till his death—on the top and forepart of his head was a slight contused wound, about an inch and a half long and not very deep—I thought it of little consequence—he had, however, some suspicious symptoms which indicated that the brain had received some slight injury—no portions of the bone ever came away; a piece of the bone became dead, and was undergoing the process of excoriation—I consider the blow had produced a slight injury to the brain, which in about nine weeks pro
duced inflammation of the membranes, and that produced death.
Q. Then you trace the death to the original blow? A. Undoubtedly.

Cross-examined. Q. If he had not received the blow he would not have been exposed to this? A. No, he underwent the operation of trepanning rather more than two months after the injury—for a considerable time Mr. Key and myself, and all the surgeons, had great hope of his recovery.

GUILTY. Aged 60.—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury .
Fined Five Pounds.
Before Mr. Justice Park.

1393.
HENRY GREIG was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of April, at
St. George the Martyr, Southwark, 1 watch, value 7l., the goods of
John Belsey, in his dwelling-house.

JOHN BELSEY . I am a watchmaker, and live at No. 126, Great Suf
folk-street, Borough, in the parish of St. George the Martyr. I have the whole house—on the afternoon of the 18th of April, I was at work in my shop, as late as four or five o'clock—the prisoner came in—I had seen him about six days before, when he came with a customer of mine, Mr. Harman—I

had a watch marked up in the window—he came in and asked me to let him look at the watch, as a friend of his, a baker, had seen it, and thought it would suit him—I showed it him—he approved of it, saying it would suit his friend, it was the sort of watch he wanted—and he left my shop, promising to meet me at eight o'clock in the evening at my shop, with his friend—he left the watch—he came about eight o'clock in the evening alone, and told me his friend was gone to some baker's shop at Stones-end, but would be back presently—he waited some time till a quarter to nine o'clock—his friend never came—while he was waiting, I had been at work on a small gold horizontal watch, and showed it to him—I then wrapped it up in paper, and put it into the drawer of a desk which stood on the table—he saw where I put it to—I then asked him if he thought his friend would come, as I wanted to go to the West-end—he said he was sure to come, and he should recommend the watch to him, as he thought it would suit him, and he desired me to put a chain on it—I then asked him to drink a glass of ale—he said he would—I sent my little boy, about eight years old, for it first, and they did not send it by him—the public-house is next door to mine—I then went for it myself, leaving the boy at the counter, and the prisoner sitting in a chair some distance from the desk—when I returned, I met him close by the door—he said, "I think my friend may have dropped in next door, allow me to go and see"—I poured him out a glass of ale which he drank, and went out immediately—he never returned—after he was gone I perceived the drawer of the desk a little open—I am sure I had shut it—I looked and missed the horizontal watch I had shown him—I ran to Stones-end and made inquiry—the next morning I found Harman who had been with him before, and he told me where to go for the prisoner, and about nine o'clock in the morning, I found him in the street close by where he lives—I asked him for the watch—he said he had never seen me before in his life—I said, "Well, will you go home with me? my wife and children will recognise you, I am certain"—he acknowledged, in going along Blackfriars-road, that he was at my place with Mr. Harman, but that was the only time—he went with me—I am quite certain he is the man, and my wife recognised him immediately—he had a much narrower-brimmed hat on in the morning when I found him, than when he came to my shop—he then had a broad-brimmed hat on—I went with the policeman, and found the broad-brimmed hat at his lodgings, No. 26, Addle-hill—I had left the prisoner in custody with the narrow-brimmed hat on—at the station house I said there was an alteration in the man, that he had a broader-brimmed hat on—I went to his house the next day.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. Have you since seen the watch? A. I have not had it in my hand—About a week ago, last Monday, I re
ceived information that the watch was pawned—that was after the exami
nation before the Magistrate—this happened on a Wednesday evening, and the next day he was taken to Union Hall, and remained until the 26th, and was then committed—when I first met him he said he did not know me—he subsequently recognised me, and said he remembered seeing me, in the presence of Mr. Harman—Mr. Harman is a respectable person, and a cus
tomer of mine—I knew very well where to find the prisoner, by inquiring of Harman—Mr. Harman said it was the first time he was in his company—I was certain I could find Mr. Harman—he had previously left me his

address—I am quite certain about the hat—when the hat was founds at his lodgings by the constable he acknowledged it was his—I found the hat in the corner of his room, and I said it was the hat he had on, and he said it was his—I think he said at Union Hall that one of them was his Sunday hat—my daughter is eleven years old—when the prisoner went with me to my house, my wife recognised him at once—my daughter was at school—I went and fetched her to the station-house, to see him—she did not recognise him at first, but as soon as he put on the broad-brimmed hat she was enabled to do so.

MARY ANN BELSEY . I am eleven years old, and live with my father. I recollect the evening when a person came into the shop to buy a watch—I was in the parlour with my father—I can see into the shop from there—my little brother was in the shop with the person—it was the pri
soner—my father went out for some ale—my little brother was in the shop at the time—the prisoner was in the first chair—there were two chairs—there is a counter and table in the shop—I saw a desk on the counter—I did not see the prisoner do any thing while my father was out—I saw him the following day at the station-house—I did not know him exactly then—I said he was the man at Union Hall—I knew him better there, because he put on a broad-brimmed hat—I am sure the person who was in my father's shop the night before had a broad-brimmed hat.

Cross-examined. Q. You only know him by the hat? A. No—when he had the small hat on I could not tell whether it was the same person or not—he struck me as not being the same person, with the small hat on.

ROBERT BRODIE (police-constable L 132.) I received information that Mr. Belsey had lost a gold Geneva watch—I was employed to trace it—I found it pledged at Mr. Higginbotham's the same night, Monday, the 6th of May, in the New-cut, Lambeth—that is near St. George the Martyr's.

THOMAS LEWIS . J am in the service of Mr. Higginbotham. I have a gold watch, which was brought about half-past nine o'clock on the evening of the 18th of April—we live about ten minutes' or a quarter of an hour's walk from the prosecutor's—we did not take it in as a pledge, but lent 3l. on it—it is not usual to take in pledges so late—I am sure the prisoner is the person—I had never known him before—I had some doubt when I first saw him, but I have not now—he did not have the same dress on as when I saw him before—he had a brown Petersham coat on then—I did not make any memorandum of the name he gave me—I did not give him a ticket—he was to come for a ticket the next day, and then he could have more money on it—I rather think he had a narrow-brimmed hat on, but I cannot swear positively—he did not come back the next day for more.

Cross-examined. Q. What was the value of the watch? A. He might have had 4l. on it if he had liked—it was worth 7l. to a wearer—we ad
vance according to what we consider the article worth—I swear to his face—his coat was buttoned up close about the neck—at that time of night it was not very light.

JOHN BELSEY
re-examined. I am sure this is the same watch—the hat is not here—the policeman who apprehended him is not here—he was not bound over.
(George Price, baker, Cornwall-road, Lambeth; and John Chalmers, baker, Little Carter-lane, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1394.
WILLIAM NASH was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of April, 1 filly, price 9l., the property of
William Prior.
MESSRS. PAYNE and DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM PRIOR . I am blind, and carry on the business of a cattle-dealer at Battersea. I had this filly nine months, and was well acquainted with it from frequently touching it—I had other cattle, and could distin
